conclusion: To determine if the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds, analyze the v-t graph.
The v-t graph plots velocity on the y-axis and time on the x-axis. The slope represents acceleration.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the graph is a horizontal line at v = 2 m/s.
The velocity is constant from t = 0 to t = 1 second, indicating no acceleration.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the graph is a straight line sloping downwards from v = 2 m/s to v = 0 m/s.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, there is constant negative acceleration.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the graph slopes downwards from v = 0 m/s to v = -2 m/s.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, there is constant negative acceleration.
In the first second, the velocity is constant. In the second and third seconds, the velocity changes linearly with time.
Yes, the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds.
